myst/cwexports/d1.html.title: D1
myst/cwexports/d1.html.description:
A Primer to Reading a Sourcebookplease please feel free to ask me questions because you are diving into the ~ point of a currently 2 year project; it will be a mess. this glossary will try to define important terms without making you read a full chapter about that thing, but if you are at all interested in reading the full chapter for that topic shoot me a message on teams or 4696493152, i'll gladly take all the eyes i can get A TTRPG sourcebook is not read like a normal story. It is in the 2nd omniscent person. It is written to the GM (Game master/manager), who is the one running the game for the players, who create characters to play through the story (campaign). It's function over form. While I try to keep the writing itself interesting, getting the content across clearly is more important than the GM having fun reading the book. While you will see just one chapter of the book, there is a whole lot more than just X chapters. This glossary will try to summarize important relevant terms but a good ~100 pages of setting and gameplay comes before this. It is non-linear. A 'chapter' more or less consists of a location and everything that could happen there depending on what the players do. Some things may never come up and some will turn out completely different depending on who plays. While the majority is story, there is chunks relating to gameplay (which will be fairly obvious). I will try to mark gameplay stuff that is unimportant from a strictly narrative perspective. Character descriptions come in an Appendix (I will attach relevant character descriptions at the end) Notes about my writing specifically: I use light language. https://TH3-S4LM0N.github.io/Swearing.html I use a boatload of backlinks in my vault, none of these will work on my website but i cant be bothered to remove them manually
Incarnation: Ikkown is a sexless world. When people die, the natural process of incarnation takes over. The soul will leave it and move on, but the body will regrow over time, ranging from just weeks to years depending on how damaged the body was. After that period, a new soul will be placed within and the body will live again. There are 77,777 bodies, there always have been, and always will be.
Ikkown: Teelul for world. Ikkown is the physical world and setting as a whole. Ikkown is a medium fantasy setting. High fantasy is a setting where basically all modern tech exists, but is explained away with magic etc, while low fantasy is medieval times except that weird woman in the forest is actually a witch and the Chupacabra did actually rape your peasant daughter. In medium fantasy, not everybody and their dog is throwing fireballs but the 'fantastic' elements of the setting do play a major role.
Numein: The Numein are cast-down demigods of Ikkown who have fooled mankind into believing they are true gods. There are 7, comprising Madiven, the Triad, and the Triptych. Each of the Numein represent one of the vices of mankind. Teelul: The language spoken before Teirian common.
The Forgotten One/Schietor: This is God (not literally but a hard analogy). He created the The Numein, the Numein created the world. He cast them down. Mankind fell for a belief in the lesser deities of the Numein while The Forgotten One fell silent for a time.
Vampyres: vampyres in Myst are stripped down compared to a typical fantasy vampire. Becoming a vampyre is 2 steps: 1. Contract Nihirizmus, which a disease manifestation of internal nihlism 2. Get bit by a vampyre. Once a body is infected, even incarnation won't heal it. vampyres are normal people except they need to drink blood to live and burn in sunlight ('stripped down' as in no sleeping in coffins, silver bullets or stakes, no superstrength, no turning into a bat. there are no upsides to vampyrism). vampyrism is an analogy for the sinful nature of man. Human/Drow/Elf/Telsh: The 4 major races of Ikkown.

Douris: The major continent that most of this campaign is set on. Raxake: is the kingdom in control of Douris and Myst. Myst: An island west of Douris, it is a vassal state of Raxake. Myst is notable as the sun has not risen on Myst in ages.Pilgrim
Penreim (pen-rame) is a crypt near the quiet fishing outpost of Mebut, on the northern tip of Myst. The newly incarnate leaving the crypt is a rare but not surprising sight, and the village is a welcoming place for those new to this world, providing a place to stay while they gather their bearings. And it is so for the Pilgrim; for as is customary in Ikkown, the character will be referred by the common translation of their crypt's name: Pilgrim.
Chapter 1 covers the incarnation and beginning of life for the Pilgrim, and their stay in Mebut before venturing into the wider world to seek purpose in life. In it they will meet companions to bring, and discover a bastard curse at their very core.This tale begins with incarnation. Read the following:In the cold and damp dark of a tarnished casket, you arise. The wood is not nailed down, and slides easily, allowing you to stand straight. You are alive. You stand within a crypt, walls inlaid with many a casket same as your own. In the shadows there is complete silence. If you close your eyes you could believe you were not alive, but the cold, dead air against your skin says otherwise.
Penreim is split into three rooms; two crypts, and one entrance hall with a shrine to the Numein. In the deepest room of Penreim, the Pilgrim incarnates. Equipment. Next to their casket lays gifts and relics of their previous inhabitant, including various equipment pieces. This includes the starting equipment from the characters creation.
Veritas. As the Pilgrim enters the second room, they may see a figure on the other side of the room with a Perception check of 15, lowering as they get closer to the figure. Once the Pilgrim makes themself known, Veritas will spin with dagger in hand, threatening not to get any closer, thinking the Pilgrim is a guardsmen or another grave robber like herself. She will relax upon hearing the Pilgrim is neither thing. As is customary, she will offer the Pilgrim a helping hand in getting their footing in this new life if the Pilgrim doesn't turn her over for grave robbery. Upon this agreement, she will become the first companion to join the Pilgrim's journey.
Wendigo. As the party approaches the shrine room of the crypt, a Perception check of 14 will reveal a scuffling sound, like a large creature ripping into something. Inside the room is a Wendigo, ripping into a fresh corpse laid in the crypt. It is weakened, with only half it's normal Hit Points, and obvious crossbow wounds. In it's injured form it's Strength is reduced to 8, and it's bite attack only does 1c4-1 damage. Upon the party entering the room, it will immediately charge the Pilgrim and attempt to bite it. After a taste of the Pilgrim's flesh though, the Wendigo will turn and flee in disgust. Unbeknownst to the party at the time, the Pilgrim's nature as a vampyre makes an atrocious meal for a Wendigo.
Exit. After the Wendigo flees, the party will exit into the permanent night air of Myst and see the lights of Mebut down towards the shoreline. Upon exiting Penreim, the party levels up.

Mebut is a sleepy fishing outpost on the northern tip of Myst, it's only draw being that it is the closest place one can dock when sailing from Lethuis. It's residents are well accustomed to the newly incarnate, living so near to a crypt, although it is still not a common occurrence.
Veritas. Upon entering Mebut, Veritas will inform the Pilgrim that she has a room in the Sleeping Giant inn, and she is headed there to rest, and the Pilgrim may stay with her for a rest. Afterwards they must head to Capidum, the governing city of Myst to register the Pilgrim.
Raxaken Military. A ship of Raxaken soldiers returning from their drafted service has docked in Mebut just hours ago, and most of them are milling around Mebut, in the Sleeping Giant, or still by the ship.The Sleeping Giant inn is, like the rest of Mebut, not soon to wake up. The tavern is rather lively this travel though, as the returned soldiers make merry with the meager stock of drink the Giant has to offer.
Soldiers. The soldiers filling the Sleeping Giant are mildly imbibed and open to conversation. Upon discovering the Pilgrim is newly incarnate, they drunkenly sing a strange song about life and death that is culturally sung in celebration of the incarnate. The soldiers then begin to talk about Raxaken politics, home, and the terrors of existence, and the Pilgrim may listen in. Their questions about the new world will be gladly answered by the soldiers. Geoffrey. In a corner of Sleeping Giant away from the soldiers rabble is a man polishing a fine crossbow with a grim look on his face. Upon approach, he will snap out of it and greet the Pilgrim warmly. He recognizes the Pilgrim is not a soldier, and not one of the regular faces of the Giant, and asks what brings them to Mebut. Upon learning that the Pilgrim is headed to Capidum, he proposes they travel together, as he is headed in that direction as well. If the Pilgrim accepts, he will join the party's travels.
Gudus. At one of the tables, a game of low-stakes Gudus is taking place. Here the Pilgrim will be taught by one of the soldiers and may have their first game.
William. If the Pilgrim did not encounter William at the Docks, they will find him in the Sleeping Giant. See B. Docks for details.
When the Pilgrim is ready to lay their head, they may rest in Veritas' rented room. In the midst of their rest, the Pilgrim will awake. Read the following.You awake with a burning desire, a hunger. Not a need for meat or mead though, but a feeling as though the very essence of your existence is seeping through the cracks in your ribcage. Blood. All at once, instinct takes over. You need blood.
Unbeknownst to the Pilgrim, their vampyrism has awakened after it's long sleep in the crypt. They must feed. The Pilgrim may make a Lore check; a 10 will recognize their condition as vampyrism, while a 15 will bring to mind important knowledge of Nihirizmus and how the spread of their curse may happen.
Veritas. Veritas is the easiest target, in the same room as the Pilgrim. Veritas does believe Nihirizmus though, and feeding on her will turn her, but the Pilgrim does not necessarily know this, though they may have inferred it through a combination of Lore and Insight, to know of Nihirizmus and recognize it in Veritas respectively. Soldiers. All throughout the Sleeping Giant, soldiers are resting or drinking or gambling. An isolated one of them would make easy pickings. Mebut. Outside the Giant, while most of the town is asleep, some sailors or merchants are still at work, while various degenerates roam the streets.
Abstinence. A Pilgrim who passes a Wisdom check of DC 18 may exert their willpower and hold themselves from sating their thirst. They will suffer from the effects of abstinence though (placeholder for a backlink to the vampyre doc on chastity).After slaking their palette, the Pilgrim returns to a not-quite-peaceful rest. Upon resting, the party levels up, and chapter 2 ends.
At the docks, a ship of discharged Raxaken soldiers has docked, and is currently unloading various belongings and other goods sent with it for transport. The captain of this regiment (Veteran) is overseeing the proceedings.
William. Standing near the ship is a rare sight. A Telsh soldier who seems rather lost is searching his pack. On approach he kindly and sternly greets the Pilgrim, asking if they know the way to Capidum. William is looking for a traveling partner to return to Capidum and see his family along the way. If the Pilgrim accepts, William will join the party and stay the night at the Sleeping Giant.ToDo: More dock stuffA short side quest here would be nice. The docks need to be here, but are rather empty.
William is a Telsh refugee turned drafted soldier returning to his closest friends after his tour of duty. The people who took him in when he was a newly incarnate Telsh refugee mean the world to him.
William is a stern but kind man, easily trusting but not easily tricked. The destruction he saw in Telok and as a soldier after have made him grizzled and wise beyond his years. All he wishes for is too return home and rest. While William is not a fanatic devotee of the Numein, he sees them as gods with power over Ikkown. William always keeps his cool and handles any situation with reason and compassion. He cares deeply for those close to him. He does not speak often but when he does it is firm and wise.
Veritas is a drow grave robber suffering from Nihirizmus. She is the first companion encountered by the Pilgrim. Veritas is suffering from Nihirizmus and internal conflict over the worth of her life. She sees no point in living, but hasn't yet the guts to commit suicide.
Veritas is one of the people who, because of Nihirizmus, can see the truth of the Numein, and their lack of real power. She is not often vocal about this, for slandering the Numein can bring intense persecution and is even criminal in some areas. Veritas is not a readily open person as her views are contrary to most of Ikkown, but she sees the Pilgrim as a yet unbiased blank slate, and one who she may be open with as they have not yet been overcome by the rampant zealotism of most of Ikkown. Veritas is friendly but not easily trusting. She will offer a hand to one in need, but will not turn her back after. Veritas is nihilist and apathetic to the grand state of the world. Veritas speaks in common slang and is at home on the street.

myst/cwexports/plot-outline.html.title: Plot Outline
myst/cwexports/plot-outline.html.description:
Hello Creative WritingThis is the rough plot outline i turned in for assignment 6, it's not especially detailed as it covers a lot but I figured I should include itThis is strictly a story outline (not setting)Excerpt from Chapter 1. Kingdoms, History, & Politics During the Age of Vrax, a new disease spread, this one of the mind. Unlike most diseases, caused by bad scents, imbalance of the humors, or the conjunction of the heavens, Nihirizmus was an idea, a primordial truth: Life is pointless. I live and I die, and nothing I do will last eternally. And as simple as that, you are infected. This infection has no effect on it's own though. This disease comes in two parts. No scholar knows how the first one was created, but it is abhorrent. The vampyre. Once infected with Nihirizmus, you are susceptible to contracting the same terrible nature as it's host from the bite of a vampyre. Another thing that makes this disease unique, is that it is the only thing the wonder of incarnation cannot heal. Once a body is a vampyre, a body is ever a vampyre.
As vampyrism spread in the Age of Vrax, a new group formed, the Coven, a coalition of vampyres in Douris. As it grew, it set it sights on the isle of Myst. Vampyres burn in the sunlight, and a place where the sun never rises was viewed as a safe haven for their kind. And so the Coven infiltrated Myst, and planned an assault, to be led by their Arch-Vampyre, the most powerful vampyre to walk Ikkown, a sorcerer and swordsman. For 6 barters war raged in Myst, the Drow who had made it their home and the vampyres seeking theirs.
The vampyres won. All had gone in their favor. But in a desperate moment, the governor of Myst sacrificed what the Drow valued most to save their land: independence. He called upon Raxake to aid their fight. Within hours, the full legions of Raxake arrived on Myst's shores, outnumbering the Coven 12 to 1. It was a bloodbath. When the Coven was defeated, the Arch-Vampyre was brought to Raxake, tied to a stake upon the highest mountain to watch the sunrise, and burn to only ashes. The ashes were placed in the vampyre's home crypt in a small fishing town in Myst, if only to a recognize a true warrior, even if an abhorrent beast. This was the first war.
Once the threat had passed, Raxake's military did not return to Douris. The weakened Drow could not fight them back, and so Myst became a vassal state of Raxake. The body the player incarnates in is the body of the Arch-Vampyre. They don't learn such until later on though
this map is bad10 chapters (nothing to do with 10 deliverable assignments, chosen well before that, it's because 10 is max level. leveling up at the end of each chapter). Each chapter has a Teelul name with it's common translation. It goes unstated that throughout the main plot, I also will add some side quests and companion quests; this is a primary campaign plot summary. Penreim (Pilgrim) The Pilgrim (how the book will refer to the pc, newly incarnated people in Ikkown are named after where they incarnated until they come into their own and name themselves) incarnates in Penreim crypt in Mebut, a sleepy little fishing town on the northern tip of Myst. The Pilgrim meets Veritas in said crypt and she is the first companion. They leave the crypt and stay in Mebut for a day, before heading to the city of Capidum to register the Pilgrim. Some side quests and foreshadowing are in Mebut When staying at the inn that night, you are overcome by your vampyrism and must feed, discovering your affliction. who you feed on has consequences as Veritas has Nihirizmus and will become a vampyre if you feed on her. Dokutum (Purpose) The Pilgrim travels to Capidum to register, but the city is in the midst of revolt. Revolutionary drow seek Myst's independence from Raxake. The gates are closed the party must pass through the Undercity to get to Capidum 2 parts The Wilds In the wild on their way to the undercity the party encounters William and Geoffrey (rounding out a full 4 man party before reaching the undercity) The Undercity (see map at the bottom) The Undercity is a slum inside a giant cave beneath Capidum, and the original home of the Drow who were banished from Douris In the Undercity, the party will be introduced personally to the 3 major factions Revolutionaries: Drow who want Myst back Loyalist: Raxaken nobles quelling rebellion The Coven: existence is known to the pc at this point, not much else. They request meeting with the pc in Capidum once the pc enters the Undercity
The pcs motivation changes here. Obviously registration is out of the question during an uprising, but as the pc is a vampyre, they are involved with Coven activities by association whether they like it or not Getting into Capidum requires help from one of the 3 factions Haven't really dug that deep yet, idk what those 3 paths are Somewhere in here you also meet more companions Chapter ends upon entering Capidum Peccai Orfale (Original Sin) This chapter revolves around resolving the revolution. The characters may (and are encouraged too) meet with the Coven in Capidum. Here they will learn the Coven is back stronger and once again wishes to take Myst for their own. They want to recruit the pc bc they are the Arch-Vampyre, but they do not tell the pc this yet 3 paths to resolving the revolution: Loyalists pc helps assassinate the revolutionary leader Coven is pulling the loyalists strings and the Coven takes over Myst Revolutionaries pc helps assassinate the Raxaken governor Coven swoops in in the disarray with overwhelming force and takes control of Myst Coven pc helps assassinate the Raxaken governor explicitly for the Coven to take over Myst Coven takes over Myst No matter what the Coven will take Myst by storm Depending on which faction you side with, they will offer you a companion to assist who will stay with you afterwards By the end of this chapter you have had a chance to recruit all the companions Nihirizmus (Nihilism) & Suki bum Suki (I am that I Am) Non-plot notes These 2 chapters blend together because there aren't any distinct fights yet. I'm not sure where I will draw the line. This is where theology comes into play. This is also where the story really starts to branch and so from here onward my descriptions will be more and more vague. I plan to makes flow charts for each chapter and the plot as a whole eventually.
At this point, your companions do not know you are a vampyre, but your companions and people you meet have made their minds very clear about vampyres with all this talk of the Coven. Nihilism has been drilled home. You (the vampyre, the sinner) are a worthless wretch
Each companions individual story also has a midpoint at which they are infected with Nihirizmus: they realize the Numein are false, and their life is pointless. That midpoint for most of them is somewhere around here. At the start of this chapter, your Arch-Vampyrism is revealed. Depending on your previous allegiances The Coven will tell you
The Vobidashi, a vampyre splinter group who seek something greater in life will This is all tactless and too your companions faces. They will react accordingly (they will not turn to violence, as they all have Nihirizmus and are questioning their worldview) Through the Vobidashi, you will also learn of Helen Cagth Suporits. She is the new Arch-Vampyre of the Coven. Helen is a theological rock in this story (not in a good way). She long ago Contracted Nihirizmus and vampyrism
Concluded the Numein are false deities Concluded there must be a greater being Concluded "kiri bum suki" (loosely translates to "fuck God") Decided to take "kiri bum suki" literally and attempt to kill God
By "theological rock", I mean thus: Helen is a Nihirizmus infected power hungry vampyre who knows her life is worthless. She is the pc. The problem is that by the end of the story, she will not be able to overcome her pride and bow down before a great God.
Unknown to most of the Coven, Helen aims to drink the blood of the Numein and call The Forgotten One down and kill him. Numein note:
The Numein are demigods who are literally in Ikkown. You can roll up to Libeva's temple in Lethuis and she is literally there. I do this because I think it helps personify what each of them represent very strongly. If you sided with the Coven previously, she will tell you herself. The Vobidashi will inform you most likely otherwise.
Since the creation of Ikkown, The Forgotten One has fallen silent for generations. This is his first appearance in recorded history.
The Forgotten One will appear to the pc at this central point. This is when everything will be made clear. The Numein are false, The Forgotten One created all, and still rules almighty. Helen can suck all the Numein blood she wants, she can't kill God but she's still gonna be really powerful and it will be pretty crappy for everyone else.
Fun gameplay tie-in: The Forgotten One is a Warlock patron that becomes accessible at this point
At the end of this section, whether you side with The Forgotten One or not, Helen must be stopped from consuming the Numein's blood cause that's basically the end of the world as we know it. 6-8: Valsai Kwaarum, Valsai Yonum, & Valsai Mathia (False Evil, False Good, & False Apathy) These chapters can be played in any order at this point These chapters are effectively 7 boss fights against the parts of the Coven Helen has sent to retrieve Numein blood. Which order the Coven goes to them is chosen at random, but Madiven is always last. The party can also choose the order they wish to visit the Numein. Each Numein has one of 3 outcomes The Coven got there first, and it's too late
Party and Coven arrive at the same time, combat ensues. Party arrives first and warns the Numein of what will happen. The party may stay with a Numein to defend them personally, just warning a Numein does not guarantee the Coven won't get to them Yonum and Kwaarum are the Triad and Triptych respectively, each centered in one of the major citites, each city having 3 major temples, 1 for each Numein. This effectively boils down to 6 timed side quests in 2 different cities and 1 major quest on Madiven's throne island
How many Numein the party saves will determine the difficulty of Helen's final fight. If they fail to save any of them, it's practically impossible. If they save 7, Helen will be a pushover (statistically nigh impossible). The party is expected to save ~3 Shi no Umbruw no Moorti (The Valley of the Shadow of the Death) The Valley of the Shadow of the Death is where the thinnest point in the veil between Okultos and Ikkown rest, and where Helen will go after the Numein are dealt with. The players will be level 10 here. This chapter is for the most part a dungeon crawl to Helen's boss fight. Kyusus (Salvation) Really haven't thought this far yet because there are so so so many ways this could go All the endings boil down to the SSS Accept Salvation
The Forgotten One can redeem your wretched form (salvation)
You may reject The Forgotten One and live in Nihirizmus (slavery) Kill yourself (suicide)
Companions Veritas: Drow nihilist grave robber rogue Already has Nihirizmus when you meet her this close to committing suicide but decides to help you out when she finds you newly incarnated
Knows the Numein are a fraud from the start Addresses the skeptic, the nihilist, and the logician. Geoffrey: Human monster/bounty hunter I've had like 100 different ideas for Geoffrey's story and I'm still not settled yet but he had a partner who turned into a Wendigo and that's the start of his track to Nihilism (Wendigos like vampyres will be used as analogy for sinful nature (same goes for lycanthropes)) address the outcast William: Telsh refugee soldier Drafted into the Raxaken military after fleeing Telok, returns after his service to find that his "family" has disappeared (they were killed by Geoffrey's wendigo) address the common man Luther: free will exploration warlock tbh my first draft of this guy is completely illegible and i wrote it at like 3am. it says he's a forgotten one warlock but he can't be because the pc has to be the first forgotten one communication in the game so he needs a rework address free will Eren: Numein devoted crusader
Eren is a crusader (class, not like an in-world templar) who is completely devoted to the Triad and will have her world view fall apart as she discovers the Numein are a sham address other religions These 2 are just ideas To-be-named 1: absurdist vampyre who is recruited from the coven in chapter 3 or 4 To-be-named 2: addict address the tied down, the addicted, those who believe but can't simply pick up their cross Helen Cagth Suporits described above
The Forgotten One God

myst/cwexports/swearing.html.title: Swearing
myst/cwexports/swearing.html.description:
Here is a do/don't/replace on swearing.
 Hell Not lore friendly, hell doesn't exist  Damn
 Bastard "something that is spurious"
"an offensive or disagreeable person"
"of abnormal shape or irregular size"
(sex doesn't exist so it's not male bitch)  Bitch Old English meaning is female dog and I don't know why I would ever need to refence female dogs  Shit Teelul: gloval, meugloval (bullshit)  Fuck Teelul: kiri, kiri dont (fuck you)  (insert non-sexual crude reference to the body) Teelul: Lunus (catch all term) Me swearing The Bible says to let nothing foul exit your mouth. I interpret this by meaning, not by word. Saying fuck as an exclamation is fine but fuck you is saying something foul and targeted at a person. I think cursing is crude in general though, and overuse of curse words makes them lose their meaning. I swear rarely for emphasis, but I don't think there's anything inherently sinful about words. Characters swearing In complete isolation, I have no problem with writing characters that swear out the ass (haha) and do sinful things that sinful people do. However, not everybody shares that opinion and ultimately what I make has to get approval from people who don't agree.

headers.heading: my take on swearing for the 2 people that will ever see this

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the more connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.

info_allowResizing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be resized

info_allowCollapsing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be collapsed

info_rightDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the right sidebar

info_leftDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the left sidebar

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_sourcePath.description: The local path to the source .html file which will be included.

info_allowFoldingLists.description: Whether or not to allow lists to be folded

info_allowFoldingHeadings.description: Whether or not to allow headings to be folded

info_siteUrl.description: The url that this site will be hosted at

info_authorName.description: The name of the author of the site

bodyClasses: publish css-settings-manager styled-scrollbars is-focused show-inline-title show-ribbon
